Guide to the Dorothy Hayden Cudahy Irish Memories Collection AIA.001
Finding aid prepared by Marion Casey, Kaitlyn Medley, Rebecca Altermatt
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 70 Washington Square South New York, NY, 10012 (212) 998-2630 tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu

Description is in English Describing Archives: A Content Standard
September 2012
Edited by Rachel Searcy for compliance with DACS and Tamiment Required Elements for Archival Description
Dorothy Hayden Cudahy Irish Memories Collection AIA.001
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive
40.5 linear feet in 15 record cartons, 1 manuscript box, 3 oversize flat boxes, and 27 oversize boxes.
Bulk, 1940-1990 1925-1997; bulk 1940-1990 The collection contains the personal papers of Dorothy Hayden Cudahy, host of Irish Memories, as well as materials from her husband John J. Cudahy and her father, John Hayden. Among the papers are included correspondence, financial documents, editorials written by John Cudahy, and materials related to professional achievements, such as Dorothy Cudahy's position as the first female St. Patrick's Day Parade Grand Marshall and John Cudahy's assignment in the United States Army. The collection also contains material from the Irish Memories radio program which John Hayden hosted until his death in 1943, after which Dorothy took over. She remained the host until the 1990s. Of particular interest in the collection is a series of photographs docuemting the life of Irish Americans in New York, many collected by her father of famous musicians, although many others unidentified. Several photographs of Dorothy Hayden Cudahy at organized events or with the Dorothy Hayden Cudahy's Irish Steppers are also included. A small series of ephemera containing holiday cards and newspaper clippings completes the collection. Materials stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact irishamerica.archives@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to research visit. Materials are in English.
Hayden Cudahy, Dorothy, 1922-2010
Processing Information Note
Inventories are available for the 33 rpm and 78 rpm records, but not for the 45 rpm records. Some of the reel tapes for Series VI have been transferred to cd. These instances are noted in the reel listings. The cds themselves contain a number but no descriptive labels. These are sometimes found on the related reel tape, but not in all instances.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements Note
Please contact an archivist at irishamerica.archives@nyu.edu for arrangements to listen to audio materials in the collection.
Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
American Irish Citizens Committee for the Re-election of William O'Dwyer AIA 002
Mick Moloney Irish American Music and Popular Culture Collection, Part I: Commercial Recordings AIA 031.1
Access Restrictions
Open to users without restriction.
Arrangement
Collection is organized into five series, each of which are arranged alphabetically. (Please note there is no box 38)
Series I. Dorothy Hayden Cudahy, 1936-1991
Series II. John J. Cudahy, 1925-1989
Series III. Photographs, 1919-1988
Series IV. Ephemera, 1940-1997
Series V. Commercial Recordings, 1957-1989
Series VI. Irish Memories Radio Program Recordings, 1944-1997
Scope and Content Note
The Dorothy Hayden Cudahy Irish Memories Collection consists of the personal papers of Dorothy Hayden Cudahy, her husband John J. Cudahy, and her father John Hayden. Materials include correspondence, photographs, ephemera, financial records, editorials written by John Cudahy, musical recordings, radio broadcast recordings, and material objects. The majority of the collection consists of materials related to the weekly Irish Memories radio program, including records, recordings of the program, playlists, administrative documents, and notes for interviews. The collection documents not only a wide range of Irish and Irish American music, but also reflects forty years of radio broadcasting directly aimed at the Irish community in New York City.
Separated Materials
Gaelic Athletic Association of New York Collection AIA 028
James A. Hayden Papers AIA 033
Preferred Citation
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; Archives of Irish America, Tamiment Library, New York University Libraries.
Historical/Biographical Note
Dorothy Hayden Cudahy (1922-2010) was born May 29, 1922 in Manhattan. She is the daughter of James Hayden, a native of Ballyraggett, Co. Kilkenny, and Delia Brennan, a native of Curry, Co. Sligo. She married John Cudahy (1920 -1994), the son of Co. Clare immigrants, in 1947 and they had one son, Sean (1950 – 1997). In 1960, Dorothy Hayden became one of the first meter maids for the New York City Department of Traffic and by 1982 retired as the Chief of Administration of the Bureau of Enforcement of the NYC Transportation Department. In 1984 she became the first woman, as well as the first American-born person, to be elected president of the Kilkenny Association. In 1989 she was again honored as the first woman Grand Marshall of the New York City St. Patrick’s Day Parade. She and John Cudahy were active all their lives in numerous Irish organizations, both as members and officers.
James Hayden, a well known emcee and columnist for the Irish Echo, began broadcasting the Irish Memories radio program in 1930 over local station WEVD. Upon his death in 1943, his daughter succeeded as the program's host and continued broadcasting until the late 1980s. The weekly programme consisted of musical selections, news, advertisements and occasionally interviews. In addition to her program, in 1950, Ms. Cudahy created a group called the Dorothy Hayden Entertainers with dancers, musicians and entertainers. In 1951 the group appeared on the Ed Sullivan show.
Immediate Source of Acquisition Note
The papers of Dorothy Hayden Cudahy were personally donated to the Archives of Irish America at New York University in 1995.

Series I. Dorothy Hayden Cudahy, 1936-1991
1.5 linear feet
1936-1991
Scope and Content Note
Materials in this series consists of newspaper clippings, correspondence, memoranda, material objects, and financial records documenting Dorothy Hayden Cudahy’s personal and professional life, including her career in the New York City Department of Traffic, the Irish Memories radio program, her step dance troupe, and her involvement with various Irish and Irish American organizations. Of note are music playlists for the radio show and materials concerning Dorothy Cudahy’s campaign to become the Grand Marshall of the New York St. Patrick’s Day Parade.

Series II. John J. Cudahy, 1925-1989
0.5 linear feet
1925-1989
Scope and Content Note
This series consists of correspondence, financial records, newspaper editorials, and photographs concerning the life and interests of John J. Cudahy. Topics include Gaelic games matches, Cudahy’s service in the United States Army during World War II, and his involvement in Irish and Irish American organizations.

Scope and Content Note
This series consists of photographs of individuals, groups, and events Dorothy Hayden Cudahy witnessed or participated in, including weddings, graduations, social gatherings, musical performances, events for Irish and Irish American organizations, and dance performances by the Dorothy Hayden Cudahy’s Irish Steppers.

Series IV. Ephemera and Material Objects, 1940-1997
0.5 linear feet
circa 1940s, 1997
Scope and Content Note
This series consists of greeting cards, newspapers, material objects, and ephemera collected by Dorothy Hayden Cudahy. Of note is the football from the 1947 Cavan-Kerry All-Ireland Senior Football Championship held at the Polo Grounds in New York City.

Series V. Commercial Recordings, 1957-1989
30.5 linear feet
1957-1989
Scope and Content Note
This series consists of approximately 1,200 33 rpm and several hundred 78 rpm albums collected by Dorothy Hayden Cudahy and John Cudahy for the Irish Memories radio program. The albums were acquired directly from the artists or purchased during trips to Ireland. The 33 rpm LPs in the collection include recordings made in New York, Boston, and other parts of North America, in addition to some made in Dublin but pressed in New York. A wide variety of Irish music is featured, including both domestic and international artists, and ranging from sean nos singing, ceili bands, show bands, and popular songs. Traditional music, for example, ranges from performances in Ireland to the recordings of its proponents who emigrated to the United States. Because many musicians produced their own albums or those of other musicians, the collection documents Irish musicians’ mobility and their ability to assemble in different arrangements over the decades. Illustrated record jackets provide a collection of images, originating both in Ireland and the United States, targeted for Irish American consumption. Liner notes and sleeves offer information on performers, especially on some of the less documented traditional artists, such as Felix Doran, “The Last of the Traditional Pipers.”
Musicians and musical groups represented in the collection include The McNulty Family, the Gallowglass Ceili Band, the Tulla Ceili Band, the Clancy Brothers, the Boys of the Lough, the Bothy Band, Clannad, the Chieftains, and the Wolfe Tones. Some of these groups incorporate Celtic and American folk elements into the traditional form. Individual artists include John McCormack, Michael Coleman, Willie Brady, Delia Murphy, Anne Greehy, Michael O’Duffy ( 1959-1970), Birdie Gallagher, Carmel Quinn, Teres Duffy, Ruby Murray, Frank Patterson, Connie Foley, Mary McGonigle, Dermot O’Brien, Jackie Roche (1957-1974) and Paddy Noonan. Of particular interest are a collection of Comhaltas Ceoltoiri Eireann tours of the United States and Canada, circa 1972-1989 (incomplete); two tribute albums to President John F. Kennedy (including his address to Dail Eireann); and the albums of various New York Emerald Society Pipe bands.

Series VI. Irish Memories Radio Program Recordings, 1944-1997 36-39
1.75 linear feet
undated
Scope and Content Note
This series consists of cds and cassette tapes of the Irish Memories radio program. The weekly program, began by James Hayden and continued by Dorothy Hayden Cudahy following his death, consisted of musical selections, news, advertisements, interviews, and other segments. Information regarding specific playlists, sponsor announcements, and other show notes can be found in Series I whereas information on particular musical artists can be found in Series IV.
